metadata.case_name: Members of Waqf Committee, Darga Sharif, Bahraich v. Sunni Central Board of Waqf, United Provinces of Agra and Oudh

facts.text: The suit relates to a shrine and tomb known as Darga Hazarat Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi situated in village Singha Parasi and properties appurtenant to it.
Plaintiffs (appellants) are members of the Waqf Committee, Darga Sharif, Bahraich, claiming declaration that properties are not governed by United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act, U.P. XIII of 1936.
Suit filed on October 18, 1946 as Regular Suit No. 25 of 1946 against respondent 1 (Sunni Central Board of Waqf), with trustees as pro forma defendants.
Respondent 1 purported to exercise authority over properties under the Act, issuing notification on February 26, 1944 declaring them Sunni Waqf under s.5(1).

Trial court (Civil Judge, Bahraich) on April 15, 1947 held properties not waqf under Act, suit within time under s.14 Limitation Act, partly upheld s.53 notice plea; granted partial declaration and injunction.

High Court (Allahabad, Lucknow Bench) in F.C. Appeal No. 50 of 1947 on April 22, 1953/24th February, 1954 reversed trial court, held properties waqf, suit barred by s.52 limitation and incompetent without s.53 notice; dismissed suit.
Syed Salar Mahsood Ghazi buried in Singha Parasi; tomb became pilgrimage site with Urs and offerings.
Properties endowed by Emperors of Delhi; accretions from savings and offerings.
Managed by Khuddams of the Darga.
Oudh annexed 1856; properties confiscated, revived in fresh settlements.
Sanad granted 1859/1860 to Fakirulla (head khadim) for rent-free tenure of Singha Parasi for Darga maintenance.
Inayatulla (Fakirulla's son) suit No.1/1865 dismissed November 11, 1870; proprietary rights vested in endowment, management rights recognized.
1872 complaint of mismanagement; committee report February 20, 1877 recommended jury including khadims.
Government took possession under Pensions Act XXIII of 1873 post Deputy Commissioner report August 31, 1878.
Inayatulla suit 1892 for possession decreed by trial court, reversed July 20, 1897; held Government interference improper under Religious Endowments Act XX of 1863.
Government suit No.9/1902 u/s.539 CPC (present s.92); decree December 3, 1902 vesting properties in trustees, framing scheme.
Scheme operated till 1934; Suit No.1/1934 for injunction against management; District Judge order May 7, 1934 restricting fund use.
Suit No.1/1940 with Advocate-General sanction for removal of committee and fresh scheme; decreed October 16, 1941, reversed on appeal March 7, 1946 with minor amendments.
Act passed 1936; respondent 1 constituted; notification February 26, 1944; called for budget, audit, contributions u/s.54.
Appellants (most committee members) disputed waqf status.
Plaint para 11 admits Darga waqf but exempted u/s.2(ii)(a) and (c).

legal_issues.text: Are the properties in suit governed by the United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act, U.P. XIII of 1936?
Is the suit barred by limitation under s.52 of the Act?
Is the suit maintainable without notice under s.53 of the Act?

petitioner_arguments.text: Properties in suit are outside operative provisions of the Act; not waqf as defined; respondent 1 acted illegally without jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act, s.2(ii)(a) and (c)

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit not barred by s.52 limitation as appellants not mutawalli or 'person interested in a waqf' since they deny waqf existence; s.52 does not apply.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act, s.52; Limitation Act s.15

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit saved by s.15 Limitation Act due to order in Suit No.1/1940 staying institution; notification did not cover Darga/offerings, so s.53 notice not required.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Limitation Act s.15; United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act s.53

respondent_arguments.text: Properties form waqf as defined by Act; respondent 1 duly constituted Sunni Central Board authorised to supervise.
Suit barred by one-year limitation u/s.52(2) from notification date.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act s.52

respondent_arguments.text: Suit incompetent without statutory notice u/s.53.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: United Provinces Muslims Waqfs Act s.53

court_reasoning.text: Does not decide if properties waqf under Act, as suit barred by s.52 and incompetent u/s.53; assumes properties outside Act for these pleas.
'Any person interested in a waqf' in s.52 means interested in transaction held to be waqf; literal construction would make provision meaningless; appellants interested in notified properties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.52 applies; suit filed after one year from 1944-02-26 notification.

court_reasoning.text: S.15 Limitation Act requires injunction/order expressly or impliedly staying suit institution; 1941 order in prior suit does not stay this suit; strict construction, no equity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No application of s.15; suit time-barred.

court_reasoning.text: Notification covers Darga (expressly mentions tomb); offerings are income, need not be specified; s.53 applies to acts under Act and relief re waqf.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No notice given; suit not maintainable.

holdings.text: Suit governed by and barred by one-year limitation u/s.52 of Act; 'person interested in a waqf' includes those challenging waqf status of notified property.
S.15 Limitation Act inapplicable; requires stay of suit institution by injunction/order.
Suit against Central Board requires two months' notice u/s.53; not given, suit incompetent.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, confirming High Court decree; held suit barred by limitation u/s.52 and not maintainable without notice u/s.53 of the Act; did not decide waqf character.

key_quotes.text: "the expression any person interested in a waqf must mean any person interested in what is held to be a waqf."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to applying s.52 limitation despite denying waqf

key_quotes.text: "in construing provisions of limitation, equitable considerations are immaterial and irrelevant and in applying them effect must be given to the strict grammatical meaning"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the institution of a suit can never be said to be futile if it would thereby prevent the running of limitation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites Privy Council; no equity in limitation
